Laboratory of Industrial Chemistry and Reaction Engineering (TKR), Johan Gadolin Process Chemistry Centre (PCC), Åbo Akademi University Turku/Åbo FI-20500 Finland Solid activated metal foam catalysts represent a promising alternative for the continuous production of valuable sugar alcohols. Traditionally, sugar alcohols are produced industrially in batch mode using finely dispersed Raney-type nickel catalysts. In this study, novel solid foam Raney-type Ni catalysts (activated metal foam catalysts) were used for the hydrogenation of xylose to xylitol in both batch and continuous operation. Two types of catalysts were investigated: Raney-type Ni foam (Metalyst® MC 911 by Evonik Operations GmbH, Ev-F-Ni) and Raney-type Ni foam promoted with molybdenum (Metalyst® MC 981 by Evonik Operations GmbH, Ev-F-NiMo). Catalyst deactivation was primarily attributed to the accumulation of strongly adsorbed organic species on the active sites and to Ni and Al leaching, which reduced the availability of catalytically active sites. Ev-F-NiMo demonstrated a superior stability and activity compared to Ev-F-Ni, attributed to electronic interactions between Mo and Ni, which stabilize Ni in a lower oxidation state and reduce metal leaching under reaction conditions. In continuous operation, the catalysts exhibited reduced deactivation, likely due to enhanced desorption of poisons under the continuous flow of fresh feed. Although the exposure to xylonic acid, a potential poison forming on the catalyst surface, temporarily reduced the xylitol yield in continuous mode, the Ev-F-NiMo catalyst demonstrated good resilience, recovering its activity after the removal of the poisoning species. These results highlight the very attractive technical solution for the continuous production of sugar alcohols from sugar monomers, utilizing promoted Raney-type Ni catalyst that is highly active, selective and cost-effective. Its effectiveness stems from its exceptional ability to store hydrogen within its porous structure [3]. Over the years, sponge nickel has gained significant attention for its role in upgrading biomass-derived molecules into high-value compounds. For instance, it catalyzes the depolymerization of Organosolv lignin under supercritical water conditions (360 °C), yielding valuable precursors such as phenol (1.3 wt%), 4-ethylguaiacol (1.6 wt%), and cresols (2.2 wt%) for resins, polymers, and fine chemicals [4]. Similarly, sponge Ni combined with acidic zeolites in methanol-water systems has been employed to process cellulolytic enzyme lignin, achieving bio-oil yields of up to 64.2 wt%, including 27.9 wt% monophenols [5]. Raney-type catalysts have demonstrated high versatility in valorizing cellulose and hemicelluloses. They enable the direct conversion of cellulose into ethylene glycol (up to 65 % yield), a precursor for PET plastics [6], and the production of γ-valerolactone (GVL), a biofuel and platform chemical, starting from biomass-derived sugars [7]. Particularly relevant to this work, Raney-type nickel catalysts are able to selectively hydrogenate glucose and xylose into sorbitol and xylitol—polyols with applications in alimentary, pharmaceutical, and cosmetic sectors. Catalyst modifications with promoters have further enhanced the activity and stability in these applications [8–10]. Sponge nickel is produced from a Ni-Al alloy, typically composed of 50 wt% Ni, which undergoes an alkaline treatment with a strong base (NaOH or KOH) to leach out the aluminum. This leaching process creates a porous structure with a specific surface area close to 100 m²/g (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method). The Ni-Al precursor alloy is generally prepared in an induction or vacuum melting furnace at temperatures around 1400 °C [3,11–13], followed by a cooling stage using either natural convection or water quenching. The catalytic activity and stability of sponge nickel can be modified by adjusting several process and product parameters such as composition of the NiAl alloy, quenching and leaching conditions, as well as addition of promoters [3,11–13]. The result of the preparation process is a fine powder at the macroscopic level. Although active for many industrially relevant hydrogenation processes, the activity of Raney-type catalysts declines by different mechanisms such as oxidation of Ni, fouling of organic molecules on the catalyst surface and collapse of the pore structure [8,14]. Considerable improvement of the catalytic activity and stability has been observed by incorporating elements such as Zr, Mg, Mo, Cr, and Fe within the sponge Ni structure in a wide range of applications [15]. Promoters generally have the role of changing the electronic properties of Ni to modify the adsorption-desorption behavior of hydrogen and organic molecules. Nevertheless, metals such as Fe tend to increase the attrition resistance and the specific surface area [16]. For the specific case of sugar hydrogenation, Mo-promoted Raney-type Ni catalysts stand out. The addition of Mo in small amounts (≤2 wt%) improves the catalyst activity and stability attributable to the increased electronic density which enhances hydrogen dissociation and adsorption of sugar molecules, as well as stabilization of nickel in a lower oxidation state compared to the bare nickel catalyst [10,14,15]. Recent studies on Mo-modified nickel catalysts prepared by controlled pyrolysis and hydrothermal strategies have demonstrated that molybdenum can effectively promote the nickel dispersion, suppressing metal aggregation and increasing the number of accessible active sites [17–19]. Moreover, the incorporation of Mo enhances hydrogen spillover and desorption through MoO₂ surface sites and introduces electron-rich environments that stabilize metallic Ni, improving the catalytic activity under moderate pressures [17,19]. These effects are particularly relevant for aqueous-phase hydrogenation of sugars, where the catalyst stability and hydrogen availability at the metal surface are the key parameters. The improved stability and activity of promoted Raney-type Ni catalysts, coupled with their cost-effectiveness compared to other catalysts such as supported noble metals, have driven the recent research toward the development and use of Raney-type activated Ni catalysts for continuous hydrogenation processes, particularly in biomass upgrading. Shaped body catalysts, such as pellets and tablets as well as structured catalysts, for example monoliths, enable continuous operation of three-phase processes — the type commonly involved in hydrogenation processes in fine chemical and alimentary industries, such as polyol production, by far limited to batch operation with Raney-type Ni powder catalysts [20]. Several development efforts have been undertaken to create Raney-type catalysts suitable for fixed-bed applications, enabling continuous operation. For instance, granular activated Ni catalysts (2–4 mm) for the continuous hydrogenation of sugars to sugar alcohols, designed for upflow and downflow reactors [21]. Breitscheidel et al. introduced Raney-type Cu catalysts in the form of irregular "nuggets" (0.5–10 mm), optimized for the hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds in fixed-bed systems [22]. Schuetz et al. designed molded Raney-type catalysts in forms such as pellets and rings, featuring a thin activated layer to improve performance [23]. Degelmann et al. developed shell-type sponge Ni catalysts with an active layer of 0.05–1 mm thickness for sugar hydrogenation [24]. While shaped bodies such as pellets and tablets support continuous processes, they often operate with low active phase utilization due to significant mass transfer limitations within the relatively thick catalyst layers [25]. Wolf et al. developed a monolithic Raney-type Ni catalyst using thermal spraying technology. The authors melted commercially available sponge Ni powder in a thermal spraying gun powered by high-pressure oxygen-hydrogen combustion. The molten material was propelled onto a metallic monolith surface by a high-velocity gas jet, rapidly cooling to form a lamellar layer attached to the surface (thickness ≤300 µm). The catalyst was successfully applied to glucose to sorbitol and 2-nitrotoluene to 2-methylaniline a 1 L reactor [26] On the other hand, Jiang et al. developed a cage-like carbon-composed sponge Ni catalyst reinforced with in-situ grown carbon nanotubes (CNTs). The structure provides enhanced mechanical stability, significant hydrogen adsorption capacity, and good catalytic performance. The catalyst was successfully applied to the hydrogenation of n-butyraldehyde, demonstrating high selectivity and activity while reducing undesirable byproduct formation compared to conventional Ni/Al₂O₃ catalysts [27]. Similarly, Köhler et al. reported a Raney-type Ni foam catalyst, which exhibited excellent recyclability, stability, and ease of handling in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of benzene [28]. In this work, Evonik’s activated Ni foam catalysts from the Metalyst® MC 9 series, manufactured under a license from Alantum Europe GmbH [29], were used for xylose hydrogenation in continuous and semi-batch experiments. These catalysts are produced by modifying open-cell nickel foams with defined pore sizes, coating them with aluminum using an organic binder. The coated foams are heated to 650–730 °C to remove the binder and form a NiAl alloy. This alloy is subsequently treated with a strong base to selectively remove aluminum, producing the active sponge Ni structure. Promoters like molybdenum can be added during the synthesis, resulting in a porous and lightweight foam suitable for catalytic applications. The catalyst was tested both in semi-batch and continuous modes and relevant characterization techniques were utilized to elucidate the behavior of the material in selective hydrogenation of xylose to xylitol. The objective of this study is to evaluate the performance of solid Raney-type Ni foam catalysts, including molybdenum-promoted variants, in the selective hydrogenation of xylose to xylitol under both semi-batch and continuous operating conditions. The research aims to provide a deeper understanding of the deactivation mechanisms, particularly the impact of potential poisoning compounds such as aldonic acids, and to assess the potential of these catalysts for continuous processes in biomass upgrading. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and reagents The following chemicals were used: D-xylose (≥99.0 %), xylitol (≥99.0 %), D-arabitol (99.0 %), and D-xylulose (≥95 %), all purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Two solid Ni foam catalysts were provided by Evonik: Metalyst® MC 911, a Raney-type nickel foam catalyst containing 80–95 % Ni (hereinafter named Ev-F-Ni), and Metalyst® MC 981, a Raney-type nickel foam catalyst containing 80–95 % Ni and promoted with molybdenum (hereinafter named Ev-F-NiMo). 2.2 Characterization techniques Thermogravimetric (SDT 650 simultaneous thermal analyzer) were conducted with Ev-F-NiMo catalyst as fresh and used (four cycles of reuse at 90°C, 30 bar of hydrogen for xylose hydrogenation in semi-batch experiments). The samples were dried at 100 °C for 1 h. The mass of the sample was recorded from 100 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 using nitrogen as the purge gas. Pulse hydrogen chemisorption was utilized to determine the Ni surface area of the fresh and used catalysts after four cycles of reuse in the semi-batch experiments (Section 2.3.1). Three foam catalysts (≈60 mg) were placed inside the furnace of a Microtrac Belcat II (Bel-Japan Inc.) and dried at 110°C for 3 h under a flow of Ar at 50 cm3 [STP]min−1. Hydrogen adsorption was performed at 50°C using 50 cm3 [STP]min−1 of Ar as carrier gas. A mixture of 5.24 v/v % H2 in Ar was fed from a calibrated sample loop of 0.9950 cm3 [STP] using a 6/2-way valve to the sample. The pulse injection frequency was one injection every 200 s, giving 10 injections per sample. The exhaust gas from the furnace was passed over a molecular sieve to remove the humidity before flowing through a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The areas of the first three pulses were used to determine the amount of adsorbed hydrogen, and the last five pulses were used to determine the calibration factor. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was utilized to analyze the surface chemical state of the catalysts. Prior to the analysis, the samples were dried under a nitrogen atmosphere in a glove box and transferred to the XPS instrument using a Thermo Scientific transfer vessel to prevent air exposure. Measurements were conducted using a Thermo Scientific Nexsa G2 X-Ray Photoelectron Spectrometer with a monochromated Al Kα excitation source. The analysis chamber pressure was maintained below 2 × 10⁻⁹ mbar. To remove potential surface oxides formed during transport, a mild ion beam etching was applied (6000 eV/300 Ar cluster) for 30 seconds to the samples. The carbon peak (C-C 1 s) at 284.8 eV was used as the binding energy reference. The chemical state of nickel was evaluated in the Ni 2p and Ni 3p regions, aluminum in the Al 2p region, and molybdenum in the Mo 3p region. The acquired spectra were deconvoluted using the XPS PEAK 41 software, referencing binding energy values reported in the literature and characteristic peaks for each spectral region. The Ni 2p₃/₂ peak for metallic nickel was observed at 852.6 ± 0.2 eV, while the Ni 2p₁/₂ peak appeared at 870.3 ± 0.1 eV. For NiO, the 2p₃/₂ and 2p₁/₂ peaks were located at 855.9 ± 0.7 eV and 873.4 ± 0.6 eV, respectively. The satellite peaks corresponding to Ni²⁺ were observed at 864.1 ± 0.8 eV (2p₃/₂) and 881.1 ± 1.3 eV (2p₁/₂). The Ni(OH)ₓ species were assigned to 859.3 ± 0.3 eV (2p₃/₂) and 876.8 ± 0.3 eV (2p₁/₂). In the Ni 3p region, metallic nickel exhibited a peak at 65.1 ± 0.1 eV. NiO showed a peak at 67.4 ± 0.6 eV, while the Ni(OH)ₓ species displayed a peak at 69.7 ± 0.8 eV. For aluminum, the Al 2p peak for metallic aluminum appeared at 72.3 ± 1.4 eV. The Al 2p peak corresponding to Al₂O₃ was observed at 73.7 ± 1.0 eV, while the aluminum hydroxide species Al(OH)ₓ exhibited a peak at 75.9 ± 1.1 eV. In the Mo 3d region, MoO₂ (Mo⁴⁺) was identified with peaks at 230.8 eV (Mo 3d₅/₂) and 233.8 eV (Mo 3d₃/₂). MoO₃ (Mo⁶⁺) exhibited peaks at 232.3 eV (Mo 3d₅/₂) and 235.7 eV (Mo 3d₃/₂). Metal leaching was quantified by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using a PerkinElmer Optima 5300 DV instrument. Samples from the reaction mixtures were collected before and after the first and fourth cycles of the semi-batch experiments to assess the extent of leaching. 2.3 Kinetic hydrogenation experiments Semi-batch experiments were conducted in a Parr 4843 reactor autoclave with a nominal volume of 300 mL. Foam catalysts (dimensions: 4 × 4 × 1.9 mm) were fixed a SpinChem® rotating bed loaded with inert quartz balls, as shown in Fig. 1(a). To prevent air exposure, the catalyst was packed inside a water-filled vessel, ensuring that it remained submerged. After packing, the SpinChem® bed was attached to the reactor impeller and sealed with 130 g of distilled water. Separately, a 50 g xylose solution was heated to 90 °C and saturated with hydrogen at 30 bar in a preheater chamber. At t = 0 min, the preheated xylose solution was introduced into the reactor, and the rotating bed was set to 700 rpm, resulting in an initial xylose concentration of 0.14 M. This procedure ensured an air-free environment, initiating the reaction under the desired experimental conditions. At the end of each experiment, the reactor was depressurized, and the sugar solution was drained. The SpinChem® bed containing the catalyst was immersed in distilled water and rotated at 700 rpm for 15 minutes. Subsequently, the bed was stored inside the reactor filled with distilled water and argon at 1 barg. Continuous experiments were conducted in a parallel screening tubular reactor system equipped with gas flow controllers, HPLC pumps, and a back-pressure controller. The reactor packing setup is illustrated in Fig. 1(b). It consisted of quartz sand placed at the top and bottom of the catalytically active bed to aid dispersion, along with an aluminum foam (9 mm in diameter and 33 mm in length) to further distribute gas and liquid flows. Glass wool was tightly packed around the bed to prevent channeling and ensure uniform flow. During the packing process, argon gas was flowed from the bottom to the top of the reactor tubes at a rate of 100 mL min−1 to minimize air exposure. The catalyst materials employed were cylindrical pieces of Ev-F-Ni and Ev-F-NiMo, each with dimensions of 10 mm in diameter and 1.9 mm in thickness. Experiments were carried out under a hydrogen pressure of 20 bar, with a gas flow rate of 6.6 mL min−1. The effects of temperature (90–120 °C) and liquid flow rate (0.25–0.75 mL min−1) were investigated using a xylose solution with a concentration of 0.14 M. Stabilization experiments were conducted during 12 h for each catalyst. The potential poisoning effect of xylonic acid on Ev-F-NiMo was assessed through a continuous hydrogenation experiment at 120 °C, 6.6 mL min−1H₂, and 20 bar. For the first three hours, a 0.14 M xylose solution was fed at 0.25 mL/min. At t = 270 minutes, the feed was switched to a xylose solution containing 14 mM xylonic acid, and monitored for seven additional hours, after which the feed was switched back to the xylose solution to evaluate the impact of removing the poison. Xylonic acid was synthesized by oxidizing 200 mL of a 0.2 M xylose solution in a batch reactor at 60°C, using a 2 wt% Au/Al₂O₃ catalyst [30], with the particle sizes ranging from 45 µm to 90 µm. The reactor was agitated at 700 rpm, and a constant flow of 40 mL min−1 of an argon/air mixture (2:1 ratio) was maintained throughout the reaction [31]. The selectivity towards xylonic acid exceeded 99 %, as confirmed by HPLC analysis. Liquid samples from both continuous and semi-batch experiments were analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Hewlett Packard Series 1100) equipped with a refractive index detector (Technologies 1100 Series) and a Rezex RCM-Monosaccharide Ca²⁺ column operated at 70 °C. The mobile phase consisted of a 1.2 mM CaSO₄ solution at 0.6 mL min−1, and the sample injection volume was 5 µL. The weighing process for kinetic experiments and catalyst characterization followed the guidelines provided by the manufacturer. A volumetric flask was filled with distilled water, and the weight of the water (mH₂O) was recorded. The desired amount of catalyst was added to the flask, ensuring sufficient water to fully submerge the catalyst. The water volume was adjusted back to the original level, and the new mass (ms) was measured. The actual mass of the catalyst (mcat) was calculated using Eq. (1), incorporating a skeletal density correction factor (e = 1.2) specific to the nickel foam catalysts. (1) m cat = e ∙ m s − m H 2 o 2.4 Kinetic modeling To understand the behavior of the catalyst in recycle batch experiments, a kinetic model was fitted to the experimental data. The derivation of the rate equation is detailed in the Electronic Supporting Information (Section S2). The proposed reaction scheme, based on the detected species, is presented in Fig. 2. The main pathway corresponds to the hydrogenation of xylose to xylitol (r₁). Xylose can also isomerize to its ketopentose isomer, xylulose (r₂), which can convert back to xylose (r₃). Xylulose hydrogenation yields a mixture of pentitols, primarily xylitol and arabitol (also known as lyxitol), via reactions r₄ and r₅, respectively. The size difference between hydrogen and sugar molecules allows to assume a non-competitive adsorption model [32,33].The effect of the external mass transfer limitations was neglected giving the low concentration utilized during the experiments (0.14 M) and the high agitation rate (700 rpm). Internal mass transfer limitations within the catalyst pores were also disregarded, as the low concentrations used minimized their potential impact. Furthermore, the adsorption of products was not considered, since preliminary modeling efforts showed that their adsorption parameters were significantly lower than that of xylose. Consequently, the initial activity of the catalyst for each experiment was set to the final activity from the preceding experiment. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Batch experiments and catalyst characterization The catalytic performance of Ev-F-Ni and Ev-F-NiMo was evaluated through repeated batch experiments conducted under identical conditions. In the first cycle, Ev-F-NiMo exhibited significantly higher xylose conversion level ( Fig. 3a) and an initial reaction rate approximately double that of Ev-F-Ni (Fig. 3b). Although both catalysts exhibited an approximately 40 % decrease in the initial reaction rate after the first cycle, the subsequent deactivation followed an asymptotic trend, indicating a slower rate of decay. Notably, Ev-F-NiMo consistently outperformed Ev-F-Ni across all cycles. Furthermore, Ev-F-NiMo showed only half the Ni leaching observed for Ev-F-Ni during the first cycle (Figure S3), underscoring the stabilizing effect of Mo. By the fourth cycle, the Ni leaching had substantially declined for both catalysts, while the aluminum leaching remained on a comparable level. Although the catalysts displayed comparable surface areas (∼25 m²/g, Table 1), hydrogen chemisorption measurements revealed a slightly higher hydrogen adsorption area for Ev-F-Ni (1.9 m²/g) relative to Ev-F-NiMo (1.2 m²/g). After four cycles, surface blockage rendered both nitrogen physisorption and hydrogen chemisorption measurements unfeasible. Remarkably, the catalytic activity persisted: in the fourth cycle, xylose conversion reached 25 % for Ev-F-Ni and 80 % for Ev-F-NiMo after five hours. This observation suggests that the reaction conditions might partially mitigate the effects of surface blockage i.e., hydrogen and high temperature, which enable poison desorption and subsequent hydrogenation. The blocking of hydrogenation active sites also led to a marked reduction of the xylitol selectivity, particularly for Ev-F-Ni at low xylose conversions as displayed in Figs. 3c and 3d. The identified by-products displayed in Fig. 2 included xylulose (ketopentose isomer of xylose) and arabitol (stereoisomer of xylitol). Overall, the selectivity toward these by-products decreased as the xylose conversion increased, likely due to the progressive hydrogenation of xylulose to xylitol, as confirmed by the concentration profiles (Electronic Supporting Information, Figures S5 and S6). The formation of organic deposits on the catalyst surface—such as carboxylic acids, including xylonic acid in this case—has been hypothesized as a major cause of deactivation of the Raney-type Ni catalysts in sugar hydrogenation [14,36–38]. These molecules exert two principal effects: they strongly bind to the active sites and exhibit a chelating effect that enhances metal leaching. As shown by the TGA profile in Fig. 4, the used Ev-F-NiMo catalyst displayed two major decomposition events at ∼250 °C and ∼350 °C, with a total mass loss of ∼10 %. In contrast, the fresh catalyst exhibited a single decomposition event at ∼230 °C, with only 2 % mass loss. Combined with surface blockage detected by physisorption and chemisorption, these results support the hypothesis that organic deposits are the primary cause of deactivation. The oxidation state of the metal under reaction conditions is a key factor influencing the catalytic performance. Fig. 5 presents the XPS spectra in the Ni 2p and Ni 3p/Al 2p regions, including the deconvolution of the identified surface species. The Ni 2p spectra revealed peaks (average values) corresponding to metallic Ni at 852.6 eV (2p₃/₂) and 870.3 eV (2p₁/₂); NiO at 855.9 and 873.4 eV; and Ni(OH)ₓ at 859.3 and 876.8 eV. Satellite features associated with Ni²⁺ appeared at 864.1 eV and 881.1 eV. In the Ni 3p region, metallic Ni, NiO, and Ni(OH)ₓ were identified at 65.1, 67.4, and 69.7 eV, respectively. Regarding aluminum, the Al 2p signals were assigned to metallic Al (72.3 eV), Al₂O₃ (73.7 eV), and Al(OH)ₓ (75.9 eV). The XPS analysis also revealed the presence of MoO₂ (Mo⁴⁺) with peaks at 230.8 and 233.8 eV, and MoO₃ (Mo⁶⁺) at 232.3 and 235.7 eV. A complete list of binding energies and peak assignments is provided in Section 2.2 (Characterization techniques) and the Electronic Supporting Information (Table S1). The analysis of surface species ratios is summarized in Table 2, where the values derived from the Ni 2p and Ni 3p regions show a close agreement, confirming the consistency of the spectral deconvolution. In the fresh samples, the catalyst surface was enriched in aluminum (Ni(total)/Al(total) ratio ∼0.40), mainly present in oxidized forms. The Almetal/Altotal ratios were 0.18 and 0.09 for Ev-F-NiMo and Ev-F-Ni, respectively. After four reaction cycles, both catalysts showed an increased intensity at 75.9 ± 1.1 eV, consistent with aluminum hydroxide species resulting from interactions with aqueous media under reaction conditions. The Ni/Al ratio also increased the post-reaction — up to 2.62 for Ev-F-NiMo and 1.37 for Ev-F-Ni — likely due to aluminum leaching [39]. Ev-F-NiMo consistently displayed a higher proportion of metallic nickel (fresh = 0.11; used = 0.29) compared to Ev-F-Ni (fresh = 0.10; used = 0.19). This observation, combined with the promoting effect of Mo — known to modify the electronic properties of nickel and facilitate the desorption of organic species — explains the superior activity of the Mo-doped catalyst [11]. The XPS analysis of Mo species (Electronic Supporting Information, Figure S4) indicates that Mo exists in high oxidation states (6+ and 4+). Previous studies suggest that the improved stability of Raney-type Ni catalysts doped with small loadings of molybdenum arises from Mo protecting Ni active sites from oxidation [13,39]. The observed increase in the Ni(OH)x/Ni(total) ratio after use (Ev-F-NiMo from 0.36 to 0.50; Ev-F-Ni from 0.30 to 0.54) corroborates the leaching trends observed in the batch experiments. Overall, the characterization confirms that the presence of Mo not only enhances the catalytic activity but also contributes to preserving Ni in its reduced, active form. The performance of both types of catalysts in repeated batch experiments was modeled mathematically using a semi-empirical kinetic approach, as detailed in Section 2.4. Figs. 6 and 7 compare the experimental concentration profiles with the modeled ones for Ev-F-NiMo and Ev-F-Ni, with the fitted parameters listed in Table 3. The model achieved excellent agreement with the experimental data. Notably, Ev-F-NiMo exhibited a higher activity for the main reaction compared to Ev-F-Ni, as evidenced by the value of κ 1,90 ° C , which was approximately twice as high for Ev-F-NiMo as for Ev-F-Ni. Regarding the deactivation behavior, the asymptotic catalyst activity values were determined to be 0.33 for Ev-F-NiMo and 0.24 for Ev-F-Ni. Nevertheless, the deactivation parameter was significantly higher for the unpromoted Ev-F-Ni. 3.2 Continuous experiments 3.2.1 Catalyst stabilization period Fig. 8 compares the performance of the Ev-F-NiMo and Ev-F-Ni catalysts during the initial continuous operation experiment. The Ev-F-NiMo catalyst exhibited a noticeable increase in xylitol yield around 200 minutes of operation, along with a significant reduction in the isomerization by-product, xylulose. In contrast, the Ev-F-Ni catalyst showed a less pronounced increase in activity but achieved a considerable decrease in by-product formation, particularly xylulose. This behavior is likely due to improved hydrogen dispersion in the liquid phase as the catalyst bed became saturated with the sugar solution. Following this phase, both catalysts demonstrated stable performance during the time-on-stream operation. 3.2.2 Effect of process parameters The effect of the key process parameters, temperature and liquid flow rate, in continuous operation was studied using two catalyst loadings for Ev-F-NiMo. A loading of 0.25 g was used to evaluate the behavior at medium conversions, while 1.2 g of catalyst was employed to observe the concentration responses at high xylose conversions. The results are displayed in Fig. 9 and 10. As expected, the reaction temperature significantly influenced the xylitol yield. Although higher temperatures led to increased formation of by-products, the selectivity remained above 97 %. The apparent activation energy was estimated to 43.9 kJ mol⁻¹ , which is within the range of previously reported data on xylose hydrogenation [40] . At high catalyst loadings, the effect of temperature is less pronounced, primarily due to slower kinetics caused by the low concentrations of xylose in the final section of the catalytic bed. The effect of the liquid flow rate on the xylitol yield is shown in Fig. 8. Sugar hydrogenation is a relatively slow reaction; therefore, a decrease in residence time directly impacts the conversion, with increased flow rates reducing the xylitol yield. However, there is a compensating effect: low liquid flow rates imply low Reynolds numbers, which in turn result in low Sherwood numbers (Sh), i.e. low liquid-solid mass transfer coefficients [41]. 3.2.3 Effect of surface poisons The formation of aldonic acids, such as gluconic acid during glucose hydrogenation, lactobionic acid in lactose hydrogenation, and xylonic acid during xylose hydrogenation, has been identified as a critical factor contributing to the deactivation of Raney-type nickel catalysts. These acids strongly adsorb onto active sites, effectively blocking them, and their chelating properties exacerbate the leaching of active metals. Recent DFT and in situ FTIR studies further support this mechanism, showing that gluconic acid binds strongly to Ni surfaces via carboxylate groups, with a distinct IR band visible at 1722 cm⁻¹ . Given the structural similarity of xylonic acid, analogous adsorption and site-blocking behavior are probable in this case [36]. Batch experiments have demonstrated this effect, where exposing Raney-type catalysts to aldonic acid solutions prior to reaction resulted in a significant decrease in catalytic activity [8,14,38]. To investigate the impact of these compounds under continuous flow conditions, an experiment was performed in which after a stabilization time (270 min), Ev-F-NiMo was exposed to solution containing 0.14 mM xylonic acid. The results are displayed in Fig. 11. The xylitol yield showed only a modest reduction (5 %) compared to previous batch experiments, likely due to the mitigating effect of continuous flow on the poison accumulation. Interestingly, the selectivity of the isomerization product, xylulose, increased from 0.8 % to 3 %. This observation may suggest a catalytic effect of the acidic medium on the isomerization of aldoses to ketoses, a phenomenon typically promoted by Brønsted acid sites. Upon removal of the contaminant, the Ev-F-NiMo catalyst fully recovered its original activity, demonstrating the reversible nature of the deactivation under specific conditions. 4 Conclusions The results of this study demonstrated the potential of solid Raney-type Ni foam catalysts for the highly selective hydrogenation of xylose to xylitol The molybdenum-promoted activated Ni foam catalyst Metalyst® MC 981 (Ev-F-NiMo) consistently outperformed the unpromoted one (Metalyst® MC 911; Ev-F-Ni) in terms of activity, stability, and selectivity. Under continuous flow conditions, the extent of deactivation was notably lower compared to batch operation, likely due to the enhanced desorption of poisoning species under the steady feed of fresh reactants into the reactor tube. The deactivation mechanisms were primarily associated with the adsorption of strongly bonded organic species on the active sites and the chelating effects that promoted metal leaching. The incorporation of molybdenum into the catalyst structure played a crucial role in mitigating these deactivation effects by enhancing the electronic properties of nickel, thereby stabilizing the active sites and improving the hydrogen and xylose adsorption. Notably, the Ev-F-NiMo catalyst demonstrated a reversible deactivation mechanism, recovering its original activity upon the removal of poisoning compounds in continuous operation. Advanced kinetic modeling provided a comprehensive understanding of the reaction and deactivation behavior, aligning well with experimental data. This modeling approach further supported the observed superior performance of Ev-F-NiMo in terms of activity and stability. coredata.dc:description: Solid activated metal foam catalysts represent a promising alternative for the continuous production of valuable sugar alcohols. Traditionally, sugar alcohols are produced industrially in batch mode using finely dispersed Raney-type nickel catalysts. In this study, novel solid foam Raney-type Ni catalysts (activated metal foam catalysts) were used for the hydrogenation of xylose to xylitol in both batch and continuous operation. Two types of catalysts were investigated: Raney-type Ni foam (Metalyst® MC 911 by Evonik Operations GmbH, Ev-F-Ni) and Raney-type Ni foam promoted with molybdenum (Metalyst® MC 981 by Evonik Operations GmbH, Ev-F-NiMo). Catalyst deactivation was primarily attributed to the accumulation of strongly adsorbed organic species on the active sites and to Ni and Al leaching, which reduced the availability of catalytically active sites. Ev-F-NiMo demonstrated a superior stability and activity compared to Ev-F-Ni, attributed to electronic interactions between Mo and Ni, which stabilize Ni in a lower oxidation state and reduce metal leaching under reaction conditions. In continuous operation, the catalysts exhibited reduced deactivation, likely due to enhanced desorption of poisons under the continuous flow of fresh feed. Although the exposure to xylonic acid, a potential poison forming on the catalyst surface, temporarily reduced the xylitol yield in continuous mode, the Ev-F-NiMo catalyst demonstrated good resilience, recovering its activity after the removal of the poisoning species. These results highlight the very attractive technical solution for the continuous production of sugar alcohols from sugar monomers, utilizing promoted Raney-type Ni catalyst that is highly active, selective and cost-effective.
